question: Question_Section_201_06_(a)
statement:
Consider the same graph as in the
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/April_2013/Question_Section_201_05_(a)}{previous
question}, now interpreted as an internet where the vertices represent
web pages and the arrows represent links.

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{MATH307April2013Section201Q6.png}
\end{description}

\textbf{(a)} Write down the stochastic matrix associated with the
PageRank algorithm with no damping. Explain what you are doing with
vertex 6.
sols:
When $\alpha$ = 0,

The stochastic matrix P is the sum of the outgoing links and the
dangling links:

$P = \begin{bmatrix}
0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 1/6
\\ 1/2 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 1/6
\\ 0 & 1/2 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 1/6
\\ 1/2 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 1/6
\\ 0 & 1/2 & 0 & 1 & 0 & 1/6
\\ 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1/6
\end{bmatrix}$

Vertex 6 has no links leaving the site, so it is a dangling node. When
the web surfer reaches a dangling node, we assume that any page on the
internet can be chosen at random with equal probability. This is why all
the entries in column 6 of matrix \emph{P} contain the value 1/6.
hints:
Suppose when on page i, that one can move to all pages i points to with
equal probability. You are looking for the transition matrix, where
component i of the state vector on which the matrix acts represents the
probability of being at webpage i.
